job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Livingston, NJ
pros: I absolutely love this hospital. It’s beautiful, I get to park in a covered garage and there’s a Starbucks inside! Absolute heaven to an RN coming from a hospital that was in need of a makeover and we had to pay for parking. The hospital has a lot of resources for higher education and the staff are incredibly helpful and kind. Being new in a hospital is always difficult but every time I’ve asked for help from a staff member in any given area I’ve always been met with a smile and willingness to assist. I really love that.
cons: The ONLY reason I had to give this hospital 4/5 stars is the staffing issue. I know it’s happening everywhere and this isn’t specific to this hospital. However, the problem is no one from administration asks the nurses how to help solve this crisis. The nurses are seeing the effects of poor staffing and it’s causing them to flee in droves. Retention rates are awful and it’s no wonder why. My unit is a particularly vulnerable population and I thought going there would alleviate a lot of stresses of working in a hospital because they couldn’t possibly be affected by this issue. That was very naive of me- it’s everywhere. Two very easy examples but ones that NEVER want to be heard because they are expensive are MORE travelers and MORE part time positions. Nurses who are getting older or have families are begging for part time positions and they simply are not utilizing this. It would be SO helpful to fill in the gaps in staffing with part timers but we never seem to open these types of positions. It feels like the nurses are screaming in a crowded room and no one stops to listen. The answers are typically buying food and saying thank you but that isn’t what we want. We want to take care of our patients- safely. Assignments that used to be a 1:1 meaning 1 nurse to 1 patient now are 1 nurse to 3 patients. It’s stressful and leads to mistakes and carelessness, in any setting but especially an intensive care unit. Our nurses deserve better and our patients do too. If we don’t take better care of our staff by giving them the help theyre actually asking for we’re risking even higher rates of burnout. Real change begins with listening to the nurses. I hope to god they do, and soon.

job_title: Non-clinical in Somerville, NJ
pros: Having just merged with the (larger) Barnabas Health System, there are bound to be many exciting growth areas for a career-minded person. Healthcare in the USA is undergoing a lot of changes in general, so if you want to make your career in a management area, there are and will continue to be doors opening up here.
cons: The corporate culture at RWJ in New Brunswick is kind of mean-spirited.  People in mid-level positions tend to spend more energy protecting their turf and fighting inter-department battles than really trying to make the organization better.  Part of this is just the influence of the city of New Brunswick, an ugly, dirty, traffic-congested blight on the landscape that comes with an unusual attitude - kind of elitist and selfish.  It could be the association with Rutgers and the medical school, I don't know.  The CEO, Mike Antoniades, is an egomaniac who indulges in frequent bursts of abusive profanity and seems to hold a dismissive attitude toward others.  This leadership style trickles down and affects the management style throughout the whole organization, unfortunately.

review_title: Somerset Campus - Terrible place to work as a RRT
job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Somerville, NJ
pros: Well...The staff in housekeeping and maintenance are nice.
cons:
If you are a RRT, do yourself a favor and steer clear of this dungpile. They don't want Respiratory Therapists, they want robots to sign off on paperwork so they can bill for respiratory therapy.

Things you will do:
- listen to pointless griping and micromanaging by the incompetent management staff. 
- be a cog in the machine and not a critical thinking staff member. If you aren't, this facility has a ridiculous "incident reporting" system that encourages the staff to write-up every little issue rather than working through person to person as adults do.
- deliver so many non-indicated therapies that they border on fraud in order to help shore up the abysmal revenue this facility has.

Things you won't do:
- Intubate, place arterial lines, or any other skills that are at the high end of RRT scope of practice.
- Enjoy any autonomy.
- Work with professionals and be treated as such. Imagine a middle school complete with cliques and bratty attitudes. Now give them healthcare licenses and you have RWJUH Somerset.

Oh, and they pay terrible compared to other facilities in the area as well.

job_title: Unit Clerk in New Brunswick, NJ

cons: Wages were not a living wage. Few and far between raises. No bonuses. Backpay and a union that does not advocate for higher wages. Also, you can not take a staff nurse and plop them into a head nurse position and not expect there to be problems. I strongly disagree with hiring a head nurse who is from the same unit. There are cliques and that causes problems for those who are not in said cliques.

review_title: Work here without any expectation of moving up the ladder.

job_title: Patient Transporter in Somerville, NJ
pros:
Relatively cheap food in the cafeteria. 

co-workers get along for the most part because they are all united against management. 

Nice to work alone if you are introverted, but you may like patient interaction
cons:
Too many workers have gotten injured, people are overworked

They try to limit your overtime so you don't make too much money

Low pay for the nonsense you deal with, treated like you're not important, very busy and always short staffed, unequal pay opportunities for younger women, no respect, favoritism towards young males. 

Your name is "transport" rather than what is on your birth certificate. Management puts pressure on you to work faster because patients are waiting but there aren't enough workers to go as fast as they would like. 

Will easily clash with managers if you have a strong personality and can't take orders from someone telling you when you can eat lunch or have a break. If you don't ask for lunch, they may forget about you, or they can not give you one because it's so busy. 

The uniforms are ugly, they changed from scrubs to prevent patients from confusing transporters with nurses. Other workers from other departments will snitch on you if they see you sitting down even if you have no patient to move.

Know your rights and be tough skinned or they will use you. You are your own advocate so don't be afraid to speak up

Some will try to guilt trip you for not being able to work. Be smart and listen to your body if you are feeling sick or worn out from the week, don't go to work because moving those heavy patients will only make it worse. 

Seemed like slavery. They do not care about you. It's all politics. Go somewhere else if you know what's good for you.
